ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This course was part in person and part asynchronous
Discussion boards on Canvas, virtual office hours.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Through this course, I learned more about art, culture, politics, and their intersection in during the period of "the Long 1960s." I also learned how to understand global histories of resistance in the 1960s and their manifestations and art.

I gained a much more nuanced understanding of the 1960s, not just in the US and the UK, but globally. This course emphasized the art of the decade as it related to larger social political movements. The readings in this course were sometimes challenging, but because of that, I feel I became a much more thorough reader/researcher, and my writing improved.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Lee always started our seminar with a mini-lecture, which really helped to contextualize the art movement or artists about which or whom we were speaking. The student presentations were also very helpful and informative--it seemed like everyone was really engaged in their topic, and opened up very interesting conversations for the remainder of the class period. We also had asynchronous Canvas discussions which were probably my least favorite part of the course, but I appreciated that Professor Lee incorporated them to make sure that we had some time away from Zoom, and some time to think through our thoughts relative to the discussion in order to formulate further responses to the texts and class themes.

Overall, this course was really strong. It was organized, thorough, but not too overwhelming (the workload). I felt that there were high expectations for my papers, presentations, participation in virtual discussion, and discussion threads, but that it was an expectation I could feasibly meet. The readings were so well curated, and Professor Lee's presentations were succinct yet thorough. One weakness was that the discussions sometimes fell flat, but I credit this to the awkwardness of the Zoom format--it was neither Professor Lee's fault nor the students'.
Provides a really great overview/foundation in the art and history of the 60s, how to analyze art, and how to connect art to broader social movements. Loved how we also spent time outside of the US.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Lee had us do a slightly abbreviated virtual class, followed by asynchronous Canvas posts to be written one to two days after our virtual discussion.  I didn't love the Canvas posts, but I appreciated the ways in which they gave us some time to think through the class and formulate our thoughts, as well as Professor Lee making sure we weren't spending too much time on Zoom.

I think the course was as well-adapted to the virtual format as an art history course can be. Inevitably, it is unfortunate that we couldn't see the works in person at these museums, but Professor Lee's passion and strength as a lecturer brought them to life.
At times the discussion boards felt a little tedious just because the in person segments were so great that I felt like I had said everything in class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely--this class was one of my favorites that I've taken at Yale. Professor Lee's contextual mini-lectures, combined with our in-class virtual discussions and asynchronous posts led to fruitful discussion and learning.

Absolutely yes! I would recommend this to both art history majors and non-art history majors who have an interest in 1960s visual culture. Professor Lee is absolutely brilliant, and it was a joy and a privilege to learn from her.
Yes, professor Lee is easily one of the best I've had at Yale and the class is so helpful given that the 1960s is such a touchstone in history, art, film etc.
